Introduction to Haskell Lab Session

01 Nov 2014

Haskell Lab















// C++
int f( int x, int y){
    return x+y;
}
-- Haskell
f :: Int -> Int -> Int
f x y = x + y

_













Getting familiar with ghci

_













Help!

:?

_













Get information

:info

_













Shell commands

:!

_













Get the type

:t

_













Loading a file

:load

_













How to read Haskell code

_













Function arrows associate to the right

a -> a -> a -> a
a ->(a -> (a -> a))

_













Function application associates to the left

f g h
((f g) h)

_













We can partially apply functions

add a b = a + b
incrament x = add 1 x

_













Typeclasses

_ 













class Eq a where 
    (==) :: a -> a -> Bool 
    (/=) :: a -> a -> Bool
instance Eq Int where
    i1 == i2 = eqInt i1 i2
    i1 /= i2 = not (i1 == i2)

_













Ordering: Ord

Showable: Show

Enumerable: Enum

_













Alternate Haskell Syntax

_













The function right association operator, $

f (g x )
f $ g x

_













The function composition operator

f(g(h(k x)))
f.g.h.k x

_













Converting an infix function to a prefix function 

f x = x + 3
f x = (+3) x

_













Turn your functions into a pipeline of compositions

f x = 3 + 7/x
f = (3+).(7/) x

_













Avoid the 'do' notation for IO

main = do
  putStrLn "Username:"
  name <- getLine
  putStrLn ("Hello " ++ name)
          

main = putStrLn "Username:" >> getLine >>= putStrLn.("Hello " ++)

_
